Re: License #: CP170201061
Dear Mr. Rose:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
November 29, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, Area Manager, at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
R 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated
by the youth and the social service worker.
The agreement must be reviewed with the
youth at least once every 90 calendar days
and a copy provided to the youth.
Three independent living files were reviewed. Two of three files documented
independent living agreements that exceeded the 90-day time frame requirement for
review.
Repeat Violation Established:
12/09/22 Renewal, CAP Approved 12/15/2022
FOM 722-08D Treatment plans.
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who
are a member of a participating household. • Youth
ages 14 and older. • Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court ordered caregivers.
2

Seven foster care files and 17 service plans were reviewed. Six of seven files
contained treatment plans with late signatures or were lacking signatures.
Repeat Violation Established:
12/09/22 Renewal, CAP Approved 12/15/2022
FOM 801-03 Medical passport.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
Seven foster care files were reviewed. One of seven contained a medical passport
lacking updated medical information.
Repeat Violation Established:
12/09/22 Renewal, CAP Approved 12/15/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was provided regarding medical passports. Two files
contained a medical passport signature page however the entire document was
not uploaded. The document in its entirety should be uploaded.
• Technical assistance was provided regarding the documentation of foster parent
training. In three files training was not clearly documented for each parent or the
type of training was not clearly specified.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
3

The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual corrective action is as
follows. The agency submitted a corrective action plan on December 15, 2022, in
response to those rule and policy violations established during the renewal
inspection completed on December 9, 2022. The current interim inspection
established three repeat violations. The repeat violations involved R 400.12510
Independent Living Agreement, FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans, and FOM 801-03
Medical Passports. The agency CAP attained full compliance for R 400.12326
Borrowed Home, R 400.12502 Program Statement, R 400.12503 Policy and
Procedures, and FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators annual assessment was reviewed and was found to be
thorough and well written. The assessment provided detail on the agency efforts to
comply with rules and policy. The assessment addressed barriers to maintaining
compliance. The assessment also addressed disrupted placements.
Financial Overview
N/A as DHHS local office.
Staff Interviews
Staff reported feeling supported by their respective supervisors and the agency
administration. They also reported that they feel they are part of a supportive and
competent team.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is a local DHHS office. The facility is modern and well maintained.
CHRI documentation is stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
4

Safety Alert Concern: The CPA Analyst generated a safety alert on August 16, 2023.
The home did not have a door on a bedroom.
Resolution: Resolution was obtained on August 17, 2023. A bedroom door was
installed. A photo of the installed door was submitted.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
